answers.answer: What are the high dose narcotics for?  Do you have a diagnosis of pelvic pain syndrome or interstitial cystitis?  I take Pamine for IBS, which is in the same drug class as colofac, and that makes the urinary retention worse for me, and it makes my vision even blurrier so I do have to wear glasses.  Have you been checked for Sjogren's Syndrome?  They should be able to confirm that with blood tests (SSA and SSB) and salivary gland biopsy, it could also be drug induced depending what other meds you are taking.  Valium, though, I thought there were newer, more specific drugs for urinary spasm.  Hiccups could be a side effect of your bowels being slowed down, especially if you have diabetes and have foul tasting burps.

question: Bit of an odd one this.  I suffer chronic urinary retention and self-catheterize, am female early forties.  As I often go into spasm I take valium to help with this.  I asked my doctor for other options but didn't want anything that dried out my eyes, as I wear contact lenses and already have very dry eyes.  So I now have this stuff called mebeverine hydrochloride 135mg, also called colofac.  I read the patient leaflet and it is for irritable bowel syndrome, reducing spasms.Firstly would this work on the bladder?Secondly, I take high doses of narcotics, including morphine, which slow the intestine and cause constipation.  Will this medication just make things worse?One final question.  I have chronic hiccups, can this help?Haven't taken the meds yet.  Have a feeling they are not right for my problem, but maybe should try it out.  I have no symptoms of irritable bowel as far as I know.  The problem is with my bladder.  Valium works fine but for obvious reasons is not a great drug to take long term, although have been using it for years.Should I try this med.?Thanks for any advice
title: wrong medication?
